comment_text: i met travis mills

This video is absolutely incredible Destin. I was born with Spina Bifida and have always driven with hand controls. But last November 17th i had a bilateral below the knee amputation. Havent had a vehicle since, and honestly didnt know stuff like this existed. Its so awesome to see.

When I graduated high school, I worked for a car dealer for a while.  We had one customer who came in from time to time for routine maintenance that had the hand controls installed.  A person with all four limbs functional could still drive the car but the extra lever, like this gentleman had, was still there only it was configured to be operated by the right hand.  At one point, I had to park the car and tried to do that with the hand controls out of curiosity.  I was extremely cautious which was a good thing because I don't think I moved the car more than maybe 10 feet before figuring out that this wasn't going to work out well if I pushed it.  I have the utmost respect for anyone that can operate a motor vehicle this way.  It's very impressive.
What progress has been made medically to possibly regrow bones muscle an etc?

Thank you!!
Jesus machine 😁

I love this so much! I have spinal cord/disk injuries (Syringomyelia at C7 with disk protrusions and mild rotary scoliosis, bulging disks from L4-S1), carpal tunnel (both wrists but just had surgery on my left), had a previous surgery for tennis elbow (right side, service related discharge) and it's been so difficult finding a workout that I can do but you just gave me the answer to my problem!!

Destin love your personality. Your videos make my days better.

Destin, this video has really helped me focus my ambitions - I am currently a college student studying mechanical engineering and I knew I liked cars and wanted to do something with cars, but car design just seemed too boring, and I think that working to design systems for cars like this to assist the handicapped to be more independent and making cars more usable for a wider range of people is something that combines three of my favorite things:  helping other people, heavy duty problem solving, as no two people have the exact same injury and different systems work better for different people, and my liking for cars and vehicle design (Plain old vehicle design seemed too boring for me, so designing these systems is really something that stuck out to me as super interesting) So thank you very much for sharing this, I saw this video a while ago, but hadn't thought much of it until a family friend who is losing his mobility had his car outfitted, and designing these systems is what I realized I wanted to do, so thank you.

Destin, I’ve recently found your  channel and think you’re awesome. Then I saw this video and it totally shook my concept of who you are. Thank you. As a guy with a service related injury, I can’t tell you how much I appreciate this video. We owe everything to the men and women that have gone and come back a different person, whether mentally or physically. For you, seemingly a rocket-quantum-mechanic-physicist to give this video a platform, you’re a much better person than I ever gave you credit for. Thank you for being humble and kind. God bless you and your family. Thank you for being who you are.

I have a face 'thing', born with less but nothing like a lost limb. Last thing you want to do is draw attention to 'it' and make them the person who has to let you know everything is fine by giving you a 'it's all cool' act or being bright around you to make you relax. Just relax from the get-go and its fine. If they have a problem then it leads them into the right zone. Don't make them do the social dance out of awkwardness.

As a person with a disability, THANK YOU for this video.

Check out Frederic Sausset. He competed in this last 24 Hours of Le Mans and he's a quad-amputee. They had a lift to get him in and out of the car and he controlled throttle and braking with his thighs and had an attachment on what remained of his right limb to connect to the steering wheel. When he was in the car the transmission was in automatic mode but was switched to manual for his teammates. They also completed the race. It was amazing. And I'm not trying to take anything away from this man. I think both of these situations are very inspiring.

Either force him to drive a smart car like Tesla with self driving capabilities or get him off the road before he kills himself and/or someone else. 1 handed driving is NOT SAFE. You will need both hands to adequately steer the car in the case of an emergency. Where I'm from it's an automatic fail for your driving test if you drive with one hand on the steering wheel (except when changing gears), or hook/palm the steering wheel, and that's exactly what he is doing. On top of that, his mechanical hand could still slip off in the middle of traffic, and then what? Then he loses his ability to brake. How dangerous is that?

Letting him drive is basically like letting a drunkard drive. He's putting everyone on the road at risk, including himself. Terribly irresponsible scumbag move!

dosnt seem like his reaction time in the case of a accident is going to b anything near safe. im not saying he is better or worse then any of the other 90% driving moronic masses.  im all for advancement in medical technologies but this seems unsafe to others on the road and its not like the other 90% are different. then he keeps taking his hand of the wheel yup unsafe and 1/4th as capable. in any accident situation this man will need assistance from his vehicle even if he isnt injured. its cool and im happy for him but driving a motor vehicle its up to you to not to make things more dangerous and like i stated in the event of an accident and his vehicle becomes immobile what can he do about it?

I hope it's OK that I gave directly to ATF. A former coworker of mine was a wheelchair user (please don't say "confined" to a wheelchair - he was "liberated" by it). He visited a gym that was not accessible and that made no attempt to say how they could help him. Nor were they honest in admitting they couldn't help. They merely wanted his money. He declined their "offer." And that's not uncommon. It's truly gratifying that Vobora has taken the initiative in treating people as people.

PS I'm also a veteran but I served Stateside only from 1970 to 1972.

Hey Destin, it might be in your interest to check out Frederic Sausset, a quadruple amputee who has been able to take on motor racing and recently completed the 24 Hours of Le Mans.  He has some amazing technology on his race cars to allow him to compete.

Step dad had the same setup on his huge dodge truck back in 2000. Sadly he was never able to get over the funk. Not only left me and my mother but his construction company as well. ATF is doing an amazing job!

I know blind/deaf/crippled people are often way more capable than people think. So when I needed to pass a blind guy and his friend on the sidewalk, I expected the blind guy to hear me, slow down a bit and fall in line with his friend so I could pass them, like "normal" people would do. However, he did not. I realized that this was because everyone always gets out of his way, because they think he's helpless. I almost wonder whether I should've walked into him, to teach him a lesson (not meant in the mean way), but I didn't want to. Thereby contributing to the problem.

The best Job I have ever had was a summer term job in a machine shop that made an installed hand controls in cars. I also had to do some work on a vehicle that was entirely foot controlled. We did all kinds of other adaptive technology also. Super rewarding work. Thanks Destin for reminding of that job. Programs and businesses that do this kind of work often struggle with funding and awareness.

Quadriplegic working on my drivers! Couldn't agree more, ever "you're so inspirational " is nice but it is almost limiting in a way. That's why I try to only hang out with those who want to further my progress, not congratulate me on my "bravery " which is just me living my life. We are just normal people who want to be treated as such. So many people are afraid to joke around with me, and it's one of the things I miss the most. A personal thank you to destin for getting smarter on a subject that everyone should learn about but very few do!

It's amazing how technology can bring those people forward. My friend's also in a wheelchair and is even more flexible than I am.
